content: The Act may be cited as the "Common Sense Indian Gambling Reform Act of 2005" and includes provisions for consultation with state, local, and tribal governments. Section 20 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to specify conditions for Indian tribes in Oklahoma without reservations to engage in gaming activities on certain lands. The amendments include exceptions for Indian lands where the Secretary, after consultation with the tribe and relevant government officials, determines that subsection (a) shall not apply. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to grant powers to the Chairman and the Commission regarding the approval or disapproval of individuals or entities with financial interests in gaming activities. The Commission is required to identify the top 10 persons or entities involved in gaming activities. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act grants powers to the Commission to identify the top 10 persons or entities with financial interests in gaming activities and conduct background investigations on them. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act empowers the Commission to conduct background investigations on the top 10 persons or entities with financial interests in gaming activities, as well as any other individuals or entities deemed necessary by the Commission. Additionally, tribal gaming ordinances must ensure that background investigations are conducted on tribal gaming commissioners and key tribal gaming personnel. The Commission will conduct background investigations on tribal gaming commissioners, key tribal gaming employees, primary management officials, and key employees of the gaming enterprise on an ongoing basis. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to increase Commission funding from $8,000,000 to $16,000,000. Ongoing oversight of key individuals in tribal gaming enterprises will be conducted. SEC. 5. CHANGING USE OF INDIAN LAND: Amends the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act to require Indian tribes to submit an environmental impact statement and obtain Secretary's consent before using Indian lands for gaming. The Act and its amendments will not impact any existing compacts or agreements related to gaming regulated under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act.
